Award.AwardTitle: Low-cost silicon photonic biosensors for enhanced label-free detection in complex media

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT CBET - 1264174
Ratner, Daniel

The objective of this proposal is to advance silicon photonic biosensor technology towards clinical use by dramatically reducing the size and cost of the optical source while enhancing performance through (1) the combination of novel integrated silicon nanophotonic devices designed for use with low-cost lasers and (2) interfacial chemistries optimized for label-free detection in complex biological media?including blood, plasma, and serum. Specifically, they will develop highly sensitive slot-waveguide Bragg grating and ultrathin interferometer waveguide sensors that are compatible with low-cost laser sources. These devices will be designed to detect small analytes (e.g. proteins and small molecules) and larger particles (e.g. cells, cell fragments, viruses), providing the flexibility to support the diverse needs of biomedical researchers and clinicians.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Silicon photonics is a revolutionary technology based on semiconductor chips, similar to the electronic processor in your computer and mobile phone, but driven by light guided within photonic circuits. Silicon photonics has already transformed telecommunications by increasing data bandwidths 100-fold, and the technology is now poised to advance medical diagnostics through chip-scale biosensing.

A major goal for the field is to develop an affordable, disposable device that is handheld and capable of diagnosing dozens or even hundreds of diseases, requiring only a drop of blood. This is the promise afforded by the unparalleled economies of scale of silicon manufacturing applied to address unmet needs in medicine and biology. In short, the hope is that these technologies can democratize access to medical diagnostics in the same way that low cost computing has democratized access to information through the creation of the Internet. Yet, an affordable, distributed, and portable device remains out of reach without the development of photonic circuits capable of performing biological sensing in real-world biological samples such as blood, saliva, and urine using low-cost lasers. To address these needs, this project developed a variety of powerful biological sensors designed for common telecommunications lasers and capable of improved biosensing of both small molecule targets and cells.

This NSF-sponsored project resulted a number of outcomes that have significantly advanced the use of silicon photonics for use in biological sensing. Most notably, we have developed a process to support rapid prototyping and development of silicon photonic biosensors that are compatible with foundry-scale production. This has been used to create as custom process design kit (PDK), effectively a recipe for other laboratories interested in creating their own silicon photonic devices. To support the community, we have created an open-source photonic testing platform capable of automated testing and characterization of photonic devices. Manual testing of photonic circuits can consume weeks of time by a researcher, our automated system can complete thousands of tests in a matter of hours, saving hundreds of hours of labor. Instructions, including control software, for this custom platform is freely available to the community, and a small start-up company has begun selling a fully-assembled system (based on our designs) to jumpstart academic and industry labs that wish to quickly get started in the space.

In addition to developing these enabling platforms for silicon photonics research, this project has also accomplished a number of major outcomes towards advanced silicon photonics biosensing. Through the use of novel photonic circuits, we have increased the sensing performance of our devices 10-fold, enabling unparalleled biological sensitivity for multiplex chip-scale sensors. Towards demonstrating these devices in a real-world application, we partnered with the regional blood center, Bloodworks Northwest, and demonstrated the ability of our technology to perform a critical diagnostic assay to support transfusion blood services. This work has been awarded US and Canadian patents, and allowances in Europe, permitting the development of a clinical diagnostic device built around these powerful photonic circuits.

NSF support has significantly advanced the use of silicon photonics as a scalable platform for label-free biological sensing. This project has enabled the creation and dissemination of multiple platform technologies that support biosensor development by the silicon photonics community, and is now being advanced as commercial technologies for both telecom and medical diagnostic applications.
